skill.name: omakase-off
skill.description: This skill should be used as the entry gate for build/create/implement requests. Triggers on "build X", "create Y", "implement Z", "add feature", "try both approaches", "not sure which approach". Offers brainstorm-together or omakase (chef's choice parallel exploration) options. Detects indecision during brainstorming to offer parallel exploration.
skill.summary: Entry gate for build requests. Offers collaborative brainstorming or parallel exploration of multiple implementation approaches with automated testing.
skill.author: 2389-research

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. External command patterns in documentation are example git commands. High-risk crypto and C2 patterns are regex false positives triggered by benign words. This is a legitimate workflow orchestration skill.

content.value_statement: Users often struggle to choose between implementation approaches. This skill detects indecision and offers parallel exploration of different approaches, letting tests determine the best solution.
actual_capabilities: Detects build/create/implement requests and presents collaboration options
Identifies indecision during brainstorming through passive analysis
Generates multiple implementation approaches in parallel
Orchestrates git worktrees for isolated variant development
Runs automated scenario tests against all variants
Compares results and recommends the best approach
limitations: Does not execute code directly; orchestrates other skills
Relies on external skills for testing and code review
Cannot make architectural decisions without user input
Maximum of 5-6 variants to prevent combinatorial explosion

use_cases.title: New project architecture decisions
use_cases.description: When starting a new project and unsure about technology choices (React vs Vue, SQL vs NoSQL), explore both in parallel with real tests.

use_cases.title: Refactoring trade-offs
use_cases.description: Evaluate different refactoring approaches by implementing variants and comparing their test results and code quality.

use_cases.title: Feature implementation alternatives
use_cases.description: Compare different implementation strategies for complex features by running parallel experiments.

prompt_templates.title: Basic trigger
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to build a CLI todo app. Can you help me get started?
prompt_templates.scenario: User requests to build something new

prompt_templates.title: Indecision scenario
prompt_templates.prompt: Should I use JSON files or SQLite for storage? I'm not sure which is better.
prompt_templates.scenario: User expresses uncertainty about a technical decision

prompt_templates.title: Parallel exploration request
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to add authentication. Let's try both JWT and session-based approaches to see which works better.
prompt_templates.scenario: User explicitly wants to explore multiple approaches

prompt_templates.title: Complex project setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Build me a full-stack React app with a Node backend. I'm open to different approaches for the database and API style.
prompt_templates.scenario: Complex project with multiple architectural decisions

output_examples.input: I want to build a URL shortener service.
output: Before we dive into the details, how would you like to approach this?
1. Brainstorm together - We'll explore requirements and design step by step
2. Omakase (chef's choice) - I'll generate multiple approaches, implement them in parallel, and let tests pick the winner

output_examples.input: I'm not sure whether to use REST or GraphQL for my API.
output: You seem flexible on the API style. Want to explore both?
I can implement REST and GraphQL variants in parallel, then run the same scenarios against both to see which performs better.

best_practices: Let the skill detect indecision naturally during brainstorming rather than forcing parallel exploration upfront
Limit to 5-6 variants maximum to avoid combinatorial explosion
Always use scenario testing rather than manual verification for fair comparison
anti_patterns: Using omakase for trivial decisions like file naming or directory structure
Skipping cleanup of failed variant worktrees after selection
Running too many variants without focusing on the primary architectural axis

faq.question: What triggers omakase-off?
faq.answer: The skill triggers on phrases like 'build X', 'create Y', 'implement Z', 'add feature', 'try both approaches', or expressions of uncertainty like 'not sure which approach'.

faq.question: How many variants can I explore?
faq.answer: The skill recommends a maximum of 5-6 variants. This prevents combinatorial explosion while still allowing meaningful comparison of different approaches.

faq.question: How are variants tested?
faq.answer: All variants run the same scenario tests. The skill uses the scenario-testing skill to create end-to-end tests that run against all variants equally.

faq.question: What happens to the losing variants?
faq.answer: Losing variants are cleaned up by removing their git worktrees and branches. The result is documented in result.md for future reference.

faq.question: Can I use this for small decisions?
faq.answer: No. The skill is designed for architectural decisions like storage engines or frameworks. Trivial decisions like file locations should be made normally.

faq.question: What skills does this orchestrate?
faq.answer: It coordinates with brainstorming, writing-plans, git-worktrees, parallel-agents, scenario-testing, fresh-eyes, and finish-branch skills.
